Problem:
Consider a complex-valued function \( z(t) \) governed by the equation \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \), where \( \omega \) is a real constant, representing angular frequency. An integral transformation defined by \( T(z) = \int_{0}^t e^{-i\omega s}z(s) \, ds \) is applied to study its properties over time \( t \).

If an intervention \( P(z) = z + c \), where \( c \) is a complex constant, is introduced at time \( t_1 \), will \( z(T) \) for \( T > t_1 \) still only be determined by \( \omega \) and not influenced by \( c \) or \( T(z) \)?
Explanation: The intervention \( P(z) \) shifts \( z \) by a constant \( c \), altering the initial condition for the subsequent evolution. This modified initial condition changes the trajectory of \( z(t) \), making the final state \( z(T) \) dependent on \( c \) as well as \( \omega \), and is independent of \( T(z) \).
